{{tense|date=July 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use Canadian English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Shootings at War Memorial and Parliament Hill | image = Centre Block - Parliament Hill.jpg | alt = Parliament Hill's Centre Block | caption = Parliament Hill's [[Centre Block]], scene of the attack by Michael Zehaf-Bibeau | location = {{nowrap|[[Ottawa]]
[[Ontario]], Canada}} | coordinates = | date = {{Start date|2014|10|22}} | time = 9:52 a.m.{{spnd}}9:55 a.m. | timezone = [[UTC−04:00|EDT]] | type = [[Shootings]], [[homicide]], [[terrorism]] | perp = Michael Zehaf-Bibeau{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2014/10/shooter-canadian-parliament/381767/|title='Parliament Hill Is Under Attack'|author =Polly Mosendz|date=October 22, 2014|work=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}} | weapons = [[.30-30 Winchester|.30-30]] [[Winchester Model 1894|Winchester Model 94]] rifle | fatalities = 2 (including the perpetrator) | injuries = 3 | motive = }} A series of shootings occurred on October 22, 2014, at [[Parliament Hill]] in [[Ottawa]]. At the [[National War Memorial (Canada)|Canadian National War Memorial]], Michael Zehaf-Bibeau fatally shot Corporal Nathan Cirillo, a [[Canadian Army|Canadian soldier]] on [[Ceremonial Guard#Sentry duty|ceremonial sentry]] duty. He then entered the nearby [[Centre Block]] parliament building, where members of the [[Parliament of Canada]] were attending [[caucus]]es. After wrestling with a constable at the entrance, Zehaf-Bibeau ran inside and had a shootout with parliament security personnel. He was shot 31 times by six officers and died at the scene.[http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/garbled-radio-call-delayed-police-response-to-parliament-hill-attacker-rcmp-1.2403906 ctvnews.ca: "Garbled radio call delayed police response to Parliament Hill attacker: RCMP"], 3 Jun 2015{{cite report|title=Independent Investigation Into the Death of Michael Zehaf-Bibeau|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/about/house/newsroom/articles/2015-06-03-Report-e.pdf|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=Royal Canadian Mounted Police|date=22 October 2014|isbn=978-0-660-02415-8}}[http://www.parl.gc.ca/about/house/newsroom/articles/2015-06-03-Summary-e.pdf parl.gc.ca: "October 22, 2014 House of Commons Incident Response Summary"], 3 Jun 2015 Following the shootings, the [[Downtown Ottawa|downtown core of Ottawa]] was placed on [[wikt:lockdown|lockdown]] while police searched for any potential additional threats.{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/ottawa-shooting-deadly-attacks-force-canada-to-face-up-to-global-terror-threat-9814811.html |title=Ottawa shooting: Deadly attacks force Canada to face up to a global terror threat |first=Tim |last=Walker |work=The Independent |date=October 23, 2014}} A [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) investigation into the shootings is ongoing.{{cite news |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/autopsies-underway-after-ottawa-gun-rampage |title=Autopsies underway after Ottawa gun rampage |date=October 23, 2014 |work=Ottawa Citizen |first=Robert |last=Bostelaar}} The attacker, Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, was a 32-year-old Canadian [[habitual offender]] and [[substance dependence|drug addict]] from Montreal. Considered by several acquaintances to have mental issues, he had been observed by acquaintances and [[mosque]] staff exhibiting erratic behaviour. Zehaf-Bibeau, who had a Libyan-Canadian father, had [[Religious conversion|converted]] to [[Islam]] in 2004 and visited Libya. At the time of the shooting, Zehaf-Bibeau planned to leave Canada for the Middle East, living in a [[homeless shelter]] in Ottawa while waiting for the processing of his Canadian passport application. According to RCMP Commissioner [[Bob Paulson]] the "passport issue was central to what was driving" Zehaf-Bibeau. Zehaf-Bibeau made a video prior to the attack in which he expressed his motives as being related "to Canada's foreign policy and in respect of his religious beliefs." To acquaintances and co-workers, he had previously expressed support for jihadists and others in the Middle East resisting the West's intervention, but was not known to the police to be a terrorism risk. In his mother's opinion, the attack was the "last desperate act" of someone with a [[mental disorder]] who felt trapped.{{cite news |work=National Post |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/10/25/michael-zehaf-bibeau-mother-says-killing-was-last-desperate-act-of-a-mentally-ill-person/ |title=Ottawa shooting by Michael Zehaf-Bibeau was ‘last desperate act’ of a mentally ill person, his mother writes |first=Douglas |last=Quan| date=October 25, 2014 |accessdate=October 26, 2014}} Classified by the RCMP as a [[terrorism|terrorist act]] under the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]],{{cite web |url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/news-nouvelles/2014/10-24-eng.htm |title=RCMP requests public assistance |publisher=RCMP |date=October 24, 2014 |accessdate=November 13, 2014}} it was the most serious security breach at Parliament Hill since the [[Paul Joseph Chartier|1966 parliament bombing]].{{cite news|last1=Duffy|first1=Andrew |title=Day of chaos in the capital leaves soldier and terrorist dead |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/soldier-shot-at-war-memorial-in-ottawa |accessdate=October 29, 2014|work=Ottawa Citizen |date=October 23, 2014}} It took place two days after a man [[2014 Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu ramming attack|used his car to run over two Canadian soldiers]] in [[Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu]], [[Quebec]], killing one. The two incidents, which attracted international attention, raised concerns about the effectiveness of police actions to prevent terrorist attacks, the prevention of radicalization and the security measures in place at federal and provincial legislatures. The Canadian government had already prepared a bill to expand the powers and courtroom anonymity and surveillance powers of the [[Canadian Security Intelligence Service]] (CSIS), Canada's spy agency, which was due to be introduced the day of the shootings, and was postponed by the event. The government introduced new anti-terrorism measures with the ''[[Anti-terrorism Act, 2015]]''.{{cite news |work=CBC |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/csis-powers-beefed-up-under-new-bill-tabled-by-steven-blaney-1.2814314 |title=CSIS powers beefed up under new bill tabled by Steven Blaney |first=Mas |last=Susana |date=October 27, 2014 |accessdate=October 29, 2014}} Security at Parliament Hill is to be stepped up. On June 3, 2015 it was reported that "RCMP officers have started openly carrying [[submachine gun]]s on [[Parliament Hill]] as part of a visible increase to...security."http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/rcmp-brings-out-the-big-guns-to-the-dismay-of-some ==Background== On October 20, in the [[2014 Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu ramming attack]], Martin Couture-Rouleau attacked two [[Canadian Armed Forces]] soldiers. Rouleau was a 25-year-old [[French-speaking Quebecer|Québécois]] who became a [[Muslim]] [[Religious conversion|convert]] in 2013{{cite web |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/22/us-canada-attacks-suspect-idUSKCN0IB2IX20141022 |title=Canada probes Michael Zehaf-Bibeau as possible suspect in Ottawa shooting: source|work=Reuters |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} and was a supporter of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL).{{cite news |work=CBC News |first1=Mark |last1=Gollom |first2=Tracey |last2=Lindeman |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/who-is-martin-couture-rouleau-1.2807285 |title=Who is Martin Couture-Rouleau? |date=October 22, 2014 |publisher= |accessdate=October 26, 2014}} Rouleau used his car to [[hit and run|run down]] the two soldiers before being fatally shot by police after an ensuing car chase.{{cite news |work=National Post|last1=Bell|first1=Stewart|title=‘He seemed like a typical and fairly boring convert': Inside Martin Rouleau’s rapid descent to extremism |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/10/21/he-seemed-like-a-typical-and-fairly-boring-convert-inside-martin-rouleaus-rapid-decent-to-extremism/ |accessdate=October 23, 2014}} One of the soldiers, Warrant Officer Patrice Vincent, age 53, subsequently died from his injuries. The terror threat level in Canada was on October 21 raised to medium in light of Vincent's death and due to "an increase in online 'general chatter' from radical groups including Islamic State and al-Qaeda."{{cite news| work=BBC News |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-29722094|title=Canada lifts terror threat level from low to medium|date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2014 |publisher=BBC News}} In his address to the nation following the shootings on October 22, [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] referred to the October 20 incident as an ISIL-inspired terrorist attack. Although both the October 20 and 22 attacks led to the death of Canadian soldiers, the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) has ruled out any direct connection between the events of October 20 and 22.{{cite news|url=http://www.bnd.com/2014/10/23/3470864_canadian-police-no-link-between.html?rh=1 |agency=Associated Press |title=Canadian police: no link between soldier attacks |date=October 23, 2014 |work=BND |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024050638/http://www.bnd.com/2014/10/23/3470864_canadian-police-no-link-between.html?rh=1 |archivedate=October 24, 2014 |df=mdy }} ==Shootings== ===National War Memorial=== [[File:Ottawa War Memorial Sentries.jpg|thumb|Nathan Cirillo was on sentry duty at the National War Memorial, similar to the sentries in this picture, when he was fatally shot.]] Shortly before 10:00 a.m. [[UTC−04:00|EDT]], on October 22, 2014, witnesses saw Zehaf-Bibeau arrive at the National War Memorial carrying a rifle, which was later identified as a .30–30 [[Winchester Model 1894|Winchester Model 94]] lever-action hunting rifle.{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/23/canada-police-ottawa-gunman-video-passport-motive|first=Lauren |last=Gambino|title=Canadian police release video of Ottawa parliament gunman during attack|newspaper=The Guardian|date=October 24, 2014}} He was dressed in blue jeans and a black jacket, with a [[Palestinian keffiyeh|keffiyeh]] scarf over the lower part of his face.{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/22/us-canada-attacks-shooting-idUSKCN0IB1PY20141022 |title=Canada's Parliament attacked near where prime minister was speaking, Harper safe |work=Reuters |date=October 22, 2014}} He approached Corporal Nathan Cirillo of [[The Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders of Canada (Princess Louise's)]], who was one of three [[wikt:sentry|sentries]] from the [[Ceremonial Guard]] posted at the [[Canadian Tomb of the Unknown Soldier|Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]]. At close range, Zehaf-Bibeau shot Cirillo twice in the back, fatally wounding him. Cirillo, like all others who have stood sentry at the memorial, carried an unloaded firearm.{{cite news |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/soldier-shot-at-war-memorial-in-ottawa |title=UPDATE: Day of chaos in the capital leaves soldier and terrorist dead|first=Andrew |last=Duffy |work=Ottawa Citizen}} It was only minutes before the end of the sentries' shift, which ended at 10:00 a.m.{{cite news |work=Macleans |title=Bearing witness: New voices recall the Ottawa shooting |url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/bearing-witness-new-voices-recall-the-ottawa-shooting/ |first=Julie |last=Smyth |date=December 30, 2014 }} Cpl. Kyle Button and Cpl. Branden Stevenson, two other soldiers on sentry duty, attempted to stop Zehaf-Bibeau, but they were shot at by him and forced to flee to the other side of the Memorial. Zehaf-Bibeau then pulled down his scarf, held his rifle one-handedly over his head and yelled, "For Iraq."{{cite news |work=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/gunman-yelled-for-iraq-ottawa-shooting-eyewitness-1.2810689 |title=Gunman yelled 'For Iraq:' Ottawa shooting eyewitness |date=October 23, 2014}} Cpl. Anthony Wiseman, who was nearby, then attempted to stop Zehaf-Bibeau, but Zehaf-Bibeau attempted to run him over. The three soldiers then attended to Cirillo.{{cite news |work=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/hamilton/news/cpl-nathan-cirillo-s-partner-chased-gunman-military-source-1.2810548 |title=Cpl. Nathan Cirillo's partner chased gunman: military source |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=October 23, 2014 |first1=Jeff |last1=Green |first2=John |last2=Rieti}} Along with bystanders, they applied first aid to Cirillo, attempting to resuscitate him, before paramedics arrived and took him to hospital. Meanwhile, Zehaf-Bibeau returned to his vehicle, a small grey Toyota car, which was parked on the south side of [[Wellington Street (Ottawa)|Wellington Street]] behind the memorial, and drove west along Wellington a short distance to Parliament Hill, where he abandoned his vehicle. Past scattering bystanders, he ran through a gate in the fence surrounding the Parliament Hill precinct and carjacked a parliamentary vehicle assigned to [[Minister of the Crown|ministers of the Crown]], which he drove to the Centre Block parliament building.{{cite news |author1=Glen McGregor |author2=David Reevely |author3=Dean Tweed |author4=Dennis Leung |url=https://postmediaottawacitizen2.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/1023shootingupdate-gr.jpg |title=Terror in the Capital |publisher=''Ottawa Citizen'' |date= |accessdate=October 23, 2014 }} RCMP officers on patrol in the precinct witnessed the carjacking and pursued the vehicle to the base of the [[Peace Tower]]. A photograph of Zehaf-Bibeau was taken by a tourist at the war memorial during the shootings. It shows him holding the rifle and wearing a scarf over part of his face, with part of the War Memorial behind him. Ottawa police seized the camera and then took their own photograph of the image using a cellphone. French-Canadian journalist William Reymond received a copy of the photograph via the Internet, anonymously, apparently a copy of a tweet originating from the Ottawa Police of the cellphone picture. Reymond then took a picture of the image as it was displayed on his computer monitor and posted it to Twitter a few hours later after confirming the image.{{cite news |work=National Post |title=First photo of Ottawa gunman taken by tourist who witnessed shooting at National War Memorial, sources say |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/10/24/first-photo-of-ottawa-gunman-taken-by-tourist-who-witnessed-shooting-at-national-war-memorial-sources-say/}} The image was re-tweeted by an ISIL sympathizer, leading to erroneous media reports that the image originated from an ISIL Twitter account. ===Parliament buildings=== [[File:Hall of Honour-Centre Block-Ottawa.jpg|thumb|left|The Hall of Honour in the [[Centre Block]], where Michael Zehaf-Bibeau was killed in an exchange of gunfire]] Zehaf-Bibeau entered the Centre Block through the main entrance under the Peace Tower, where Samearn Son was one of two constables on duty. Son saw the rifle in Zehaf-Bibeau's hand, immediately grabbed it, and pulled it towards the floor while yelling, "Gun! Gun! Gun!" In the ensuing struggle, Son was shot in the foot and had to let go of the attacker.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-michael-zehaf-bibeau-s-movements-revealed-by-security-video-1.2810673 |title=Ottawa shooting: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau's movements revealed by security video |work=[[CBC News]]|date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} While other RCMP officers converged on Zehaf-Bibeau, Son limped out of the building and calmly told a CBC reporter outside, "I will survive."{{cite news |work=CBC News |title=Ottawa shooting: Reconstructing the Centre Block shootout |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-reconstructing-the-centre-block-shootout-1.2821338 |first=Terry |last=Milewski}} Just inside the Centre Block, Zehaf-Bibeau exchanged gunfire with security personnel and was wounded. Zehaf-Bibeau then ran along the Hall of Honour corridor toward the Library of Parliament. Pursued by RCMP officers, he passed, on his left, the door to a committee room in which Stephen Harper and the [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative]] [[Member of parliament|Members of Parliament]] (MPs) were meeting. Directly opposite was the door to another [[Caucus#In Commonwealth nations|caucus]] room, where [[Leader of the Official Opposition (Canada)|leader of the opposition]], [[Thomas Mulcair]], and [[New Democratic Party]] MPs were gathered. (The Liberals, as the third party, were holding their caucus meeting in a chamber downstairs.) During the shooting, one bullet penetrated the outer doors to the NDP caucus room. Inside their room, NDP MPs dove for cover. Across the hall, Harper was hidden in a closet while Conservative MPs made a barricade at the doors, grabbing flagpoles to use as rudimentary spears.{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Chase |title=MPs fashioned spears while Harper whisked into closet |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-attack-mps-fashioned-spears-while-harper-hid-in-closet/article21278580|accessdate=October 23, 2014 |work=[[The Globe & Mail]] |date=October 23, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Local MPs talk about the shooting on Parliament Hill |url=http://barrie.ctvnews.ca/local-mp-s-talk-about-the-shooting-on-parliament-hill-1.2065635 |accessdate=October 22, 2014 |work=[[CKVR-DT|CTV News Barrie]] |date=October 22, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Ottawa shooting: N.L. MPs recount chaos moments after gunshots heard |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/ottawa-shooting-n-l-mps-recount-chaos-moments-after-gunshots-heard-1.2808830 |accessdate=October 22, 2014|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=October 22, 2014}} Finally, Zehaf-Bibeau reached an alcove by the entrance to the [[Library of Parliament]], and hid out of sight of RCMP officers,{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-29730956|title=Footage shows bullets fired inside Canada parliament |work=[[BBC]] News |date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 23, 2014}} who ordered him to drop his gun and surrender. The location of the alcove is near the office of the [[List of Sergeants-at-Arms of the Canadian House of Commons|Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Commons]], [[Kevin Vickers]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-the-face-to-face-encounter-that-ended-the-attack-on-parliament-1.2812802 |title=Ottawa shooting: The face-to-face encounter that ended the attack on Parliament |work=[[CBC News]]|date=October 24, 2014|accessdate=October 24, 2014 |first=Evan |last=Solomon}} Vickers, a distinguished policeman, commander and administrator with the RCMP before he joined the staff of the House of Commons in 2005,{{cite press release |last1=Office of the Leader of the Government in The House of Commons |last2=Minister for Democratic Reform |date=August 24, 2006 |title=Appointment of New Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Commons |url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/appointment-of-new-sergeant-at-arms-of-the-house-of-commons-609420.htm |publisher=MarketWired.com |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} obtained a [[9mm]] [[handgun]] from a lock-box and entered the hall. Vickers' security team, which had been chasing Zehaf-Bibeau, yelled to Vickers that the suspect was hiding in the alcove. Vickers immediately ran behind the other side of a nearby column, then dove past the column and fired upward at Zehaf-Bibeau.{{cite AV media | people = Evan Solomon | title = How Kevin Vickers managed to subdue Ottawa gunman| medium = [[YouTube]] video | publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=October 24, 2014 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4wfzWJ2Hwo}} Witnesses and reports show RCMP Constable Curtis Barrett, leading the tactical formation, fired the shot that killed Zehaf-Bibeau after Bibeau fired at his direction.{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/breaking-news-oct-22/article21217602/ |title=Attack on Ottawa: Police in pursuit of multiple shooters |work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-29747228|title=Ottawa shootings: Video shows security guard Kevin Vickers holding gun |work=[[BBC]] News |date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 23, 2014}} CBC television cameras on the scene recorded over 30 shots fired in the final gunfight. Footage showed a group of RCMP officers converging near the alcove; two loud gunshots are heard, then a large number of gunshots in rapid succession, then silence. Vickers was recorded by CBC video footage walking away from the shooting site, going to the Conservative caucus room. Vickers explained to the Conservative caucus what had happened and reportedly said either "I put him down" or "I have engaged the suspect. He is deceased."{{cite news |work=The Independent |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/ottawa-shooting-sergeantatarms-shot-suspect-at-pointblank-range-after-diving-around-pillar-9818365.html |title=Ottawa shooting: 'Sergeant-at-arms Kevin Vickers shot suspect at point-blank range after diving around pillar' |first=Lizzie |last=Dearden |date=October 25, 2014 }} According to Vickers' niece: "This is the first time in his career that he's shot anyone."{{cite news |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/2014/10/22/parliament-hill-shooting-sergeant-at-arms-kevin-vickers-the-family-hero-who-took-down-ottawa-gunman |title=Parliament Hill shooting: Sergeant-At-Arms Kevin Vickers the family hero who took down Ottawa gunman |author =Michael Platt |date=October 22, 2014 |work=Calgary Sun}} Following the shooting, Harper's RCMP [[bodyguard|security detail]] arrived and evacuated him, while the Parliament buildings were put into [[wikt:lockdown|lockdown]].{{cite news |last1=Sanchez |first1=Raf |last2=Duggan |first2=Oliver |title=Canadian parliament in lockdown after shooting |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/canada/11180220/Ottawa-shooting-Canadian-parliament-in-lockdown-after-shots-fired.html |accessdate=October 23, 2014}} ==Perpetrator== {{Infobox person | name = Michael Zehaf-Bibeau | image = Michael-zehaf-bibeau.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Zehaf-Bibeau at the National War |date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2014}} ===Personal background=== According to court documents, he was born Joseph Paul Michael Bibeau, but, in 1995, his parents legally changed his name to Joseph Paul Michael Abdallah Bulgasem Zehaf-Bibeau to better reflect the other half of his heritage.{{cite book |work=Macleans |url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/michael-zehaf-bibeau-addict-drifter-walking-contradiction/ |title=Uncovering a killer: Addict, drifter, walking contradiction |date=October 30, 2014 |first=Michael |last=Friscolanti}}{{cite news |work=The Star-Phoenix |url=http://www.thestarphoenix.com/health/Michael+Zehaf+Bibeau+journey+death+Parliament+Hill/10365292/story.html |title=Michael Zehaf-Bibeau's journey to death on Parliament Hill |date=November 8, 2014}} Initial reports put out by Reuters and US-based networks{{cite news |work=NBC News |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/canadian-parliament-shooting/ottawa-chaos-soldier-killed-canadian-capital-shooting-n231506 |title=Ottawa Chaos: Soldier Killed in Canadian Capital Shooting |date=October 22, 2014 |first=Richard |last1=Esposito |first2=Erin |last2=McClam}} in the first few hours after the shooting{{cite news |work=Reuters |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/22/us-canada-attacks-suspect-idUSKCN0IB2IX20141022 |title=Canada probes Michael Zehaf-Bibeau as possible suspect in Ottawa shooting: source |date=October 22, 2014}} said the shooter was born 'Michael Joseph Hall' and changed his name after converting to Islam, but these proved unreliable and were contradicted the next day by Reuters,{{cite news |work=Reuters |title=Man who attacked Canada's parliament had troubled, transient past |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/23/us-canada-attacks-profile-idUSKCN0IC2GW20141023 |first1=Allison |last1=Lampert |first2=Julie |last2=Gordon |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=November 22, 2014}} and the major Canadian news sources in in-depth reporting.{{cite news |newspaper=Ottawa Citizen |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/michael-zehaf-bibeau-a-timeline |title=Michael Zehaf-Bibeau: A Timeline |first=Shaamini |last=Yogaretnam |date=November 6, 2014 |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}{{cite news |work=Laval News |url=http://lavalnews.ca/article/Profile-of-a-Canadian-errorist-222101 |title=Profile of a Canadian...Terrorist? |first=Cynthia |last=Abraham |date=November 3, 2014 |accessdate=November 23, 2014}} Zehaf-Bibeau grew up in Eastern Canada, including Ottawa and Montreal. His mother is Susan Bibeau, a [[French-Canadian]] Quebecer from Montreal and deputy chairperson of a division of [[Immigration and Refugee Board|Canada's Immigration and Refugee Board]]. His father is a businessman, Bulgasem Zehaf, a [[Libya]]n immigrant to Quebec who opened the Tripoli café in Montreal. Zehaf is reported to have fought in the [[2011 Libyan Civil War]]; the ''[[Washington Times]]'' reported that Mr. Zehaf had returned to his hometown of Zawiyah in Libya to join the uprising against the [[Muammar Gaddafi]] regime. The couple split up before Zehaf-Bibeau's birth, but reconciled a short while after and were married. Zehaf and Bibeau divorced in 1999. After the divorce, Zehaf-Bibeau was removed from a private school with strict discipline and put in a secondary school known for pupils fighting with other students from local schools. Zehaf-Bibeau continued to live in the Montreal area until 2007, when he spent time in Libya before moving to Western Canada to become a miner and labourer. Zehaf-Bibeau became a [[habitual offender]] with an extensive criminal record for several offences, including [[larceny]], [[drug possession]], and [[parole]] violations. He had received several criminal convictions, at least one of which resulted in a [[custodial sentence]] of 60 days' [[incarceration]]. In November 2001, just after his 19th birthday, he was convicted of possessing a false credit card and impaired driving. In 2004, he pleaded guilty to drug possession for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] and [[Phencyclidine|PCP]]. He failed to appear at the trial date in 2006, but appeared three years later to plead guilty to marijuana possession and was given a discharge. In 2011, he was charged with [[robbery]] and "uttering threats" in [[Vancouver]], but only convicted of the lesser charge of uttering threats.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/michael-zehaf-bibeau-slain-ottawa-shooter-had-criminal-record-in-quebec-b-c-1.2809562 |title=Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, slain Ottawa shooter, had criminal record in Quebec, B.C. |work=[[CBC News]] |date=October 22, 2014}} He claimed that he committed the 2011 robbery so that he would be incarcerated, in order to kick his drug habit. He received a psychiatric evaluation, but was determined to be fit to stand for trial.{{cite news |first=Kim |last=Bolan |url=http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2014/10/22/suspect-in-ottawa-shooting-charged-in-vancouver-in-2011-robbery/ |work=Vancouver Sun |title=Suspect in Ottawa shooting charged in Vancouver in 2011 robbery |date=October 22, 2014}} ===Conversion to Islam and travels=== Baptized a [[Roman Catholic]],{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/canada/11183993/Ottawa-gunman-told-fellow-Muslim-convert-the-devil-is-chasing-me.html|title=Ottawa gunman told fellow Muslim convert 'the devil is chasing me'|date=October 23, 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=October 24, 2014 |first= Philip |last=Sherwell |location=Montreal}} he converted to [[Islam]] in 2004 and had attended Sunni Muslim{{cite news |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/ottawa-gunman-was-disruptive-at-vancouver-area-mosque|title=Ottawa gunman was disruptive at Vancouver-area mosque |first=Glen |last=McGregor |newspaper=Ottawa Citizen |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} [[mosque]]s in the [[British Columbia]] cities of [[Burnaby]] and Vancouver. A mosque in Vancouver, British Columbia, expelled him. 'His behaviour was not normal,’ said David Ali, vice-president of Masjid Al-Salaam mosque in nearby Burnaby. He said: 'We try to be open to everyone. But people on drugs don't behave normally.' Also, an acquaintance recalled that he had "erratic" behaviour, he had said "the devil is after him", and was requested to stop attending the mosque after upsetting religious elders.{{cite news |title='He said the devil is after him': What we know about Michael Zehaf-Bibeau |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/he-said-the-devil-is-after-him-what-we-know-about-michael-zehafbibeau-20141023-11aljl.html |accessdate=October 25, 2014 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=October 23, 2014}} The acquaintance believed he was [[mentally ill]].{{cite news |work=The Age |url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/he-said-the-devil-is-after-him-what-we-know-about-michael-zehafbibeau-20141023-11aljl.html?skin=text-only/ |title='He said the devil is after him': What we know about Michael Zehaf-Bibeau |date=October 24, 2014}} Zehaf-Bibeau wanted to leave Canada. An associate of Zehaf-Bibeau reported he had discussed wanting to go back to Libya to study [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and Islam. At their October 23 press conference, the RCMP said his mother told them that he wanted to go to [[Syria]] to join the anti-government rebels in the [[Syrian Civil War]],{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/mps-head-back-to-work-morning-after-ottawa-shooting/article21254540/|title=Ottawa suspect tried to get passport to go to Syria |work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=October 22, 2014|first=Kathryn |last=Blaze Carlson}}{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/parliament-shooting/article21217602 |title=Attack on Ottawa: PM Harper cites terrorist motive |work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=October 22, 2014 |first1=Josh |last1=Wingrove |first2=Steven |last2=Chase |first3=Bill |last3=Curry |first4=Jill |last4=Mahoney}} but she denied this, stating that she told the RCMP that he was intending to travel to [[Saudi Arabia]]. "He thought he would be happier in an Islamic country where they would share his beliefs."{{cite news |work=Reuters |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/26/us-canada-attacks-mother-idUSKCN0IF00V20141026 |title=Canada Parliament gunman aimed to go to Saudi Arabia, not Syria: mother |date=October 25, 2014 |accessdate=October 26, 2014}}{{cite web |first=Susan |last=Bibeau |url=https://www.scribd.com/embeds/244415837/content?start_page=1&view_mode=scroll&show_recommendations=true |title=Statement of Susan Bibeau |publisher=scribd.com |accessdate=October 27, 2014}} In a telephone interview with the press, Zehaf-Bibeau's mother said she grieves for the victims of the attack, not her son. In an email to the press, she also said "I am mad at my son," and said "he seemed lost and did not fit in."{{cite news |author =CBS/AP |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ottawa-shooting-suspects-mom-i-cry-for-the-victims-not-my-son/ |title=Ottawa shooting suspect's mom: I cry for the victims, not my son |date=October 23, 2014 |publisher=CBS}} Zehaf-Bibeau arrived in Ottawa on or before October 2, ostensibly to pursue securing a passport. Zehaf-Bibeau had applied for a [[Canadian passport]] and a [[background check]] was in progress. RCMP Commissioner [[Bob Paulson]] said this issue was central in driving the attacks.{{cite news |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/ottawa-shooting-suspect-michael-zehaf-bibeau-had-very-developed-criminality-1.2067255 |title=Ottawa shooting suspect Michael Zehaf-Bibeau had 'very developed criminality'|work=CTV News |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} Zehaf-Bibeau, who also had Libyan citizenship,{{cite news |work=Daily Mail |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2805054/Mom-Canada-suspect-I-cry-victims-not-son.html |title=Video captures terrifying moment Canadian shooter arrives at Parliament waving a gun while bystanders flee as police reveal he may be a dual citizen with Libya |date=October 23, 2014}} applied for a [[Libyan passport]] renewal on October 2 and was refused the same day. Zehaf-Bibeau had received a Libyan passport in 2000 and then travelled to Libya in 2007. That document had expired, and Zehaf-Bibeau told officials that he wanted a new passport so he could visit family and friends in Libya. ===Before the shootings=== Zehaf-Bibeau had been staying at the Ottawa Mission, a [[homeless shelter]] in Ottawa near Parliament Hill. According to other residents of the mission, Zehaf-Bibeau and two other men had been trying to get a vehicle. Others said of Zehaf-Bibeau and the other two men, "You knew they were up to something shifty, pacing around a lot and everything."{{cite news |work=Ottawa Citizen |title=Shooter Zehaf-Bibeau was staying at Ottawa Mission before rampage: witnesses |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/shooter-zehaf-bibeau-was-staying-at-ottawa-mission-before-rampage-witnesses |first=David |last=Henderson |date=October 23, 2014}} The vehicle used by Zehaf-Bibeau was purchased one day before the shootings. One resident of the mission noted that Zehaf-Bibeau's mood had changed three days before the attacks, and he attributed it to Zehaf-Bibeau going back on drugs. Zehaf-Bibeau reportedly told the other residents that he was "anti-Canadian" and to pray because "the world is ending".{{cite news |work=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-michael-zehaf-bibeau-not-among-90-being-probed-rcmp-say-1.2810113 |title=Ottawa shooting: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau not among 90 being probed, RCMP say |first=Dean |last=Beeby |date=October 23, 2014}} Another resident reported that Zehaf-Bibeau had shown a lot of interest in the Parliament buildings, including asking how easy was it to get into the Parliament buildings. A day before the attack, multiple witnesses saw Zehaf-Bibeau engaged in a "heated discussion" with another man while waiting to register his purchase of the vehicle used in the shootings. According to a witness, Zehaf-Bibeau said "If soldiers bombed your family, wouldn’t you want to kill them?". Staff in the registry office asked him to lower his voice or leave. The purchase was disallowed by the office because of his out-of-province identification. The purchase was never registered and Zehaf-Bibeau pasted a piece of junk mail on the car to mimic a temporary license permit.{{cite news |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/shooter-was-overheard-talking-about-bombings-civilian-deaths |title=Shooter was overheard talking about bombings, killing civilians |first=Glen |last=McGregor |work=Ottawa Citizen}} How Zehaf-Bibeau obtained his gun has not been determined. At the time of the shootings, Zehaf-Bibeau was legally prohibited from possessing or acquiring firearms. Additionally, his previous criminal charges and convictions, history of drug abuse, and lack of a fixed address all would have prevented him from receiving a [[Possession and Acquisition Licence|Canadian Firearms Licence]]. A knife that Zehaf-Bibeau had with him on October 22 was determined to have originated from a relative's home. ===After the shootings=== On November 15, it was reported that Zehaf-Bibeau's body had remained at the Ottawa coroner's office for examination. According to the procedure to be followed by the coroner, the examination must report the entry and exit wound of each gunshot wound, and a toxicology report. After the examination is complete, his remains must be buried according to Islamic convention. The issue of accepting his body for an eventual funeral was problematic for the Ottawa Muslim Association mosque: "while denouncing what he did as a crime, a terrorist attack against a soldier who was serving the country, we say that if he's believing in God, if he's a Muslim, then he should be buried," said imam Samy Metwally. "We will give him a funeral service."{{cite news |work=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/michael-zehaf-bibeau-s-remains-still-being-examined-at-coroner-s-office-1.2836394 |title=Michael Zehaf-Bibeau's remains still being examined at coroner's office |first=Evan |last=Dyer |date=November 15, 2014 |accessdate=November 19, 2014}} However, on November 18, the coroner in an interview announced that the body was released "over a week ago". The coroner did not release the details of the autopsy, when the body was released or whom the body was released to, citing legal restrictions.{{cite news |work=Ottawa Citizen |title=Coroner released body of Parliament Hill shooter Michael Zehaf-Bibeau |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/body-of-parliament-hill-shooter-michael-zehaf-bibeau-released-by-coroner |first=Andrew |last=Seymour |date=November 18, 2014 |accessdate=November 19, 2014}} On February 26, 2015, the ''Ottawa Citizen'' reported that Zehaf-Bibeau was buried in [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]], Libya, by arrangements made by his family.{{cite news |newspaper=Ottawa Citizen |title=Michael Zehaf-Bibeau's body buried in Libya, says cousin |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/michael-zehaf-bibeaus-body-buried-in-libya-family-member-says |first=Dylan |last=Robertson |date=February 26, 2015 |accessdate=March 1, 2015}} – Hamilton ON|publisher=|accessdate=October 26, 2014}} (December 23, 1989 – October 22, 2014), a 24-year-old Canadian soldier, was killed. He was, as a chosen member of the Ceremonial Guard, on sentry duty{{cite web |url=http://news.gc.ca/web/article-en.do?nid=872739 |publisher=Government of Canada |title=National Sentry Program |accessdate=October 29, 2014}} at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at the National War Memorial when he was shot. Although several civilians immediately provided assistance for the wounded reservist,{{cite news|title=Cpl. Nathan Cirillo told he was ‘loved’ amid frantic rescue effort|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/hamilton/news/cpl-nathan-cirillo-told-he-was-loved-amid-frantic-rescue-effort-1.2811438|accessdate=October 25, 2014|agency=CBC News}} Cirillo died in hospital later that morning.{{cite news|last1=Carville|first1=Olivia|title=Soldier fatally shot on Parliament Hill identified as Nathan Cirillo of Hamilton|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2014/10/22/soldier_fatally_shot_on_parliament_hill_identified_as_nathan_cirillo_of_hamilton.html|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} Cirillo had a standard issue [[Colt Canada C7 rifle]] which, in accordance with standard practice, was unloaded. Samearn Son, a House of Commons [[Constable#Canada|constable]], was injured. When Zehaf-Bibeau arrived at the Centre Block, he was confronted by Son. Son, who was unarmed, was shot in the foot while trying to wrestle away Zehaf-Bibeau's gun. Son's actions caused a critical delay, allowing other security personnel to mobilize to stop Zehaf-Bideau.{{cite news |last1=Smith|first1=Joanna|last2=Gillis |first2=Wendy |title=Wounded security guard Const. Samearn Son hailed as hero |url=http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2014/10/23/wounded_security_guard_const_samearn_son_hailed_as_hero.html |accessdate=October 25, 2014|publisher=Toronto Star|date=October 23, 2014}} Son was treated and released by [[The Ottawa Hospital|Ottawa Civic Hospital]]. Two other unidentified people who were injured in unspecified locations were treated and released at Ottawa Civic Hospital. Corporal Cirillo's remains are buried in the very middle of the military section of Woodland Cemetery in Hamilton, Ontario. ==Aftermath== ===Ottawa=== Ottawa's downtown core was put under [[lockdown]] while a search began for a potential second shooter. Buildings under lockdown included Canada's parliament, the [[University of Ottawa]] and the [[Embassy of the United States, Ottawa|United States embassy]]. Initially, police reported a third shooting had taken place near the [[Rideau Centre]] mall at the same time. A few hours later, police corrected this mistaken report, stating that only two shootings took place. [[File:Ottawa-shootings-map.png|thumb|left|The locations of the two shooting incidents: 1. the war memorial, 2. the Centre Block]] At a press conference at 14:00, Ottawa police confirmed Cirillo's death without using his name, pending notification of his family. The RCMP confirmed Zehaf-Bibeau's death, without his name or any other details, citing the ongoing investigation. The National Defence headquarters, the parliament buildings and other government facilities remained in lockdown while a search of the area took place.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-soldier-dies-of-injuries-gunman-also-shot-dead-1.2808710 |title=Ottawa shooting: Soldier dies of injuries, gunman also shot dead|publisher=[[CBC News]] |first=Dean |last=Beeby |date=October 22, 2014}} Areas around Parliament Hill including a mall and a university remained closed for hours with buildings in lockdown, with police searching buildings room by room for shooters. Police lifted the lockdown on all public schools in and around Ottawa's downtown core at around 5:45 p.m. Parliament Hill remained under lockdown until well past 21:00 and, even after MPs and staffers were allowed to leave the Centre Block, streets directly adjacent to Parliament Hill and the National War Memorial remained closed to the public the next day.{{cite news |work=Ottawa Sun |url=http://www.ottawasun.com/2014/10/22/much-of-downtown-ottawa-in-lockdown-after-parliament-hill-shooting |title=Road closures, Parliament Hill still closed to public: Cops |first1=Danielle |last=Bell |first2=Doug |last2=Hempstead |date=October 23, 2014}} Parliament Hill reopened to the public on October 24, and Parliament Buildings tours resumed on October 27.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |url=http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2014/10/25/parliament_hill_again_open_to_the_public_tours_to_resume_monday.html |title=Parliament Hill again open to the public; tours to resume Monday |author =Canadian Press |date=October 25, 2014}} ===Nationally and internationally=== Canadian Armed Forces members in Ottawa, Quebec, and [[Atlantic Canada]] were told to stay out of uniform when not on active duty,{{cite news|last1=Husser|first1=Amy|title=CF members asked to stay out of uniform after Ottawa shootings|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/cf-members-asked-to-stay-out-of-uniform-after-ottawa-shootings-1.2066087 |accessdate=October 22, 2014|publisher=[[CTV News]]|date=October 22, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Military members in Quebec urged not to wear uniforms when off duty |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/military-members-in-quebec-urged-not-to-wear-uniforms-when-off-duty-1.2809153|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=October 22, 2014|work=CBC News}} while members in other parts of Canada were not asked to avoid wearing uniforms.{{cite news|title=No order asking soldiers not to wear military uniforms at CFB Esquimalt |url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1630385/no-order-asking-soldiers-not-to-wear-military-uniforms-at-cfb-esquimalt/|date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2014|work=Global News}}{{cite news |title=Military bases hike security, soldiers told not to wear uniforms in public |url=http://www.thespec.com/news-story/4928726-military-bases-hike-security-soldiers-told-not-to-wear-uniforms-in-public/ |date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2014 |work=Hamilton Spectator}} Further, Canadian military bases around the country heightened their security. The incident caused cancellation of a ceremony scheduled for later the same day in Toronto, in which [[Nobel Peace Prize]] recipient [[Malala Yousafzai]] was to receive her certificate of [[honorary Canadian citizenship]] from [[Stephen Harper]].{{cite news |title=PM Harper cancels Malala Yousafzai citizenship ceremony in light of Ottawa shooting|url=http://o.canada.com/news/malala-yousafzai-citizenship-ceremony-cancelled-532930 |agency=The Canadian Press |accessdate=October 22, 2014 |work=[[Postmedia News]] | date=October 22, 2014}} Although security was heightened at the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]] in [[Toronto]], all of the party leaders agreed that the day's session of Question Period should continue.{{cite news |work= CBC |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ottawa-shooting-no-credible-threat-to-toronto-police-chief-says-1.2808800 |title=Ottawa shooting: No credible threat to Toronto, police chief says |date=October 22, 2014}} In Edmonton, public tours were cancelled for the day at the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]] and security increased.{{cite news|title=Ottawa shootings: Alberta reaction |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/ottawa-shootings-alberta-reaction-1.2808945 |accessdate=October 22, 2014 |work=CBC News Edmonton |date=October 22, 2014}} The [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia]] was placed under restricted access and most constituency offices on [[Vancouver Island]] were closed as a precaution.{{cite news |first1=Katie |last1=Derosa |first2=Jack |last2=Knox |first3=Amy |last3=Smart |first4=Cindy E. |last4=Harnett |title=Legislature, CFB Esquimalt on alert; MP offices closed |url=http://www.timescolonist.com/legislature-cfb-esquimalt-on-alert-mp-offices-closed-1.1453475 |accessdate=October 22, 2014|work=[[Victoria Times-Colonist]]|date=October 22, 2014|location=Victoria, British Columbia}} [[Nova Scotia House of Assembly|Nova Scotia's legislature]], sitting that day, restricted access in the public gallery to the press and staff of the government and political parties.{{cite web|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/1245528-nova-scotia-legislature-closed-to-public-after-shootings-in-ottawa|title=Nova Scotia legislature closed to public after shootings in Ottawa|work=The Chronicle Herald |first=Michael |last=Gorman}} The [[National Assembly of Quebec]] flew its flag at half mast the evening of October 22 as a tribute to Cirillo.{{cite news|last1=Pelletier|first1=France|title=Mise en berne du drapeau du Québec de l'hôtel du Parlement|url=http://www.assnat.qc.ca/en/actualites-salle-presse/communiques/CommuniquePresse-3149.html|accessdate=October 23, 2014|publisher=National Assembly of Quebec|date=October 22, 2014|language=French}} In the United States, security was increased in [[Washington, D.C.]]: at the [[Embassy of Canada, Washington, D.C.|Canadian embassy]], United States federal government offices nearby, and the [[Tomb of the Unknowns]] at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. The [[Australian Federal Police]] increased security at Australia's [[Parliament House, Canberra|Parliament House]], as well as at the Canadian High Commission in [[Canberra]].{{cite news |first=Meagan |last=Fitzpatrick |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ottawa-shooting-draws-reaction-from-white-house-world-leaders-1.2809039|title=Ottawa shooting draws reaction from White House, world leaders|date=October 22, 2014|publisher=[[CBC News]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}} Security at the [[New Zealand Parliament Buildings]] was also tightened.{{Cite web|url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/10653842/NZ-Parliament-closes-doors-after-Canadian-shooting|title = NZ Parliament closes doors after Canadian shooting|date = October 23, 2014|accessdate = October 26, 2014 |first1=Stacey |last1=Kirk |first2=Tracy |last2=Watkins |website = |publisher =stuff.co.nz }} ==Investigation and government response== Initially, the [[Ottawa Police Service]] (OPS) said they were investigating the shooting at the war memorial, while the RCMP was investigating the shooting at Centre Block. However, on October 23, the OPS announced that the shooting had been declared a matter of national security and, as such, the entire investigation would be turned over to the RCMP. It was also announced that the RCMP had in turn asked the [[Ontario Provincial Police]] (OPP) to conduct a standard independent investigation into the response of police and security forces.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ottawa-shooting-rcmp-takes-over-investigation-opp-to-probe-police-conduct-1.2813339 |title=Ottawa shooting: RCMP takes over investigation, OPP to probe police conduct |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=October 25, 2014}}{{cite news|title=OPP to lead independent probe of Parliament Hill security|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/opp-to-lead-independent-probe-of-parliament-hill-security-1.2071640|accessdate=October 26, 2014}} Recalled were reports issued by the [[Auditor General of Canada]] on the security of the House of Commons and the Senate.{{cite web|title = Report of the Auditor General of Canada to the Board of Internal Economy of the House of Commons{{emdash}}Administration of the House of Commons of Canada|url = http://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/internet/English/parl_otp_201206_e_36890.html|at = par. 63{{endash}}78 |date = June 2012 |publisher =
